content.data: The Order Entry (ORD) file format is an ASCII format used for transferring Solid Cabinet data in a version and configuration independent form. The ORD file may contain Cabinets from multiple Catalogs with multiple door styles and options.

The ORD file has a hierarchical structure consisting of a  [Header]  section followed by  [Catalog]  and  [Cabinet]  section pairs. The [Header] section is used to set the Solid Job defaults while the [Catalog] and corresponding [Cabinet] section are used to set the Door Styles and options for a list of Cabinets. Multiple Catalogs, Door Styles and options are specified by including multiple [Catalog] and [Cabinet] section pairs in the ORD file.

For example, if all the Cabinets in a Solid Job had the same Catalog and options, the ORD file would only have one [Catalog] section followed by one [Cabinet] section. If there were some Cabinets from a different Catalog, there would be secondary [Catalog] and [Cabinet] sections. This scheme may be repeated as many times as necessary to list all the Cabinets in a Solid Job with differing Catalogs, door styles and options.
Items in red represent the Extended ORD File Format

An Extended Format allows for the creation of Walls, Floors and the placing of Moldings and Cabinets on the Walls. The created objects are visible in the Job as if they had been placed in Layout whereas in the Standard ORD format, the Cabinets are added to an Order Entry List and are not visible in the Layout views. The Walls section should precede the Moldings and Cabinets sections as the items in these sections are attached to a Wall which needs to be defined first.

The order of the entries in the [Header] and [Catalog] sections is not important. All string values should be enclosed by quotes (" "). Numbers representing dimensions should be entered matching the Unit value specified in the [Header] area.

The entries in this section reflect the Job defaults set in the property pages accessed from the Solid Layout screen. They are mostly optional but can be used to set up the defaults for the Solid Job into which the ORD file is imported. The Materials, Door Styles and Construction set here do not affect any of the Cabinets listed in the ORD file as they take all their configurations from their corresponding  [Catalog]  sections. The  [Header]  section should at least contain the Version number for future compatibility.

The Door Style, Profile and Route names should reflect the names available in the "door.ddb" Door database. If a Profile or Route is not specified, the field still needs to be present but should contain an empty string.
The Door and Drawer style entries consist of 7 comma separated fields defined as follows:

The Material Schedule and Construction Method names should reflect their corresponding names available in the "material.cvm" (Material Schedules) and "wiz_data.wdb" (Construction Methods) databases (as they are displayed in the Material Schedule and Assembly Wizard).
The "ConstructionStyle" entry should consist of one of the values:
The Interior and Exterior Finish names should reflect the Finish names available in the "material.cvm" database (as they are displayed in the Material catalog).
The Perspective entry should consist of 5 comma separated fields define as follows:

rows: File Name and Path on the Windows Mobile Device
File Name and Path on the PC
Date of the File Created/Modified on the PC

content.data: File Name and Path on the Windows Mobile Device
File Name and Path on the PC
Date of the File Created/Modified on the PC

The entries in this section are used to define Walls. The parameters reflect the Wall’s location and direction as well as its Length, Height and Thickness. If the start or end point of a Wall is the same as an existing Wall, the Walls will be joined at that point.

If this section is present, all Cabinets will be added to a Wall instead of being added to the Order Entry list and will thus be visible in the Layout view (Floor Plan, Elevation and Perspective). The optional positional parameters for the Cabinets should be filled out to place the Cabinets correctly on the Wall.
To maintain a consistent Wall numbering sequence, the Walls should be defined in a clockwise direction. This will ensure that the Walls are numbered in the order in which they are defined.
The Wall definitions should consist of 14 comma separated fields.

rows: Wall Number (1 based) Empty = Line Count
Left Wall Number (0 or Empty => No Wall Attached)
Rotation of the Radius Wall (0 = CW, 1 = CCW)
Arc Angle for the Radius Wall

content.data: Wall Number (1 based) Empty = Line Count
Left Wall Number (0 or Empty => No Wall Attached)
Rotation of the Radius Wall (0 = CW, 1 = CCW)
Arc Angle for the Radius Wall
The "Wall Type" field must be represented by one of the following values.
2 = Interior Wall ('T' Wall or extra Wall)
The format for the "Left Wall Number" field is #-x where x:
can be empty, or E to indicate the Wall is continued from Wall #, e,g., 3 or 3-E
F to indicate the Wall is attached to the front of the Wall #, e.g., 3-F
B to indicate the Wall is attached to the back of the Wall #, e.g., 3-B
L = Allow to move or to delete only
Each Window is defined in a single line comma separated consisting of 8 fields.

rows: Window - ID for CW or CV to identify

content.data: Window - ID for CW or CV to identify
The "Wall Number" field specifies the Wall
A plain number or #-F indicates the front face eg: 3 or 3-F
Each Door is defined in a single line comma separated consisting of 7 fields.

rows: Door ID - ID for CW or CV to identify

content.data: Door ID - ID for CW or CV to identify
The "Wall Number" field specifies the Wall
A plain number or #-F indicates the front face eg: 3 or 3-F
Each Appliance is defined in a single line comma separated consisting of 13 fields.

rows: Cabinet Height (Wall Oven & Refrigerator Box only)
Appliance ID – ID for CW or CV to identify

content.data: Cabinet Height (Wall Oven & Refrigerator Box only)
Appliance ID – ID for CW or CV to identify
The "Appliance Type" field must be represented by one of the following values.
The "Wall Number" field specifies the Wall
A plain number or #-F indicates the front face eg: 3 or 3-F
The entries in this section are used to define floor shapes. The parameters reflect an X-Z coordinate pair. There needs to be a minimum of three coordinate pairs to define a floor shape.
The Floor definitions should consist of a comma separated list of a floor coordinate pairs defined as follows:

The entries in this section are used to define moldings attached to a wall. The Molding type may be one of the following predefined types, "Crown", "LightRail", "Scribe", "BaseBoard", "ChairRail" or "Casing". The moldings can be created in the XZ (as done in the Plan view in Solid) or XY (as done in the Wall elevation view in Solid). There needs to be a minimum of two coordinate pairs to define a molding shape.
The Molding definitions should consist of 8 comma separated fields followed by a comma separated list of additional coordinate pairs as follows:

rows: Wall molding should be applied to

content.data: Wall molding should be applied to
Optional fields for additional coordinate pairs.
The Molding axis can be either "XZ" to specify Molding laid out in Plan view or "XY" to specify Molding applied to the face of a Wall.
If the axis is specified as "XZ", the 4 th  field specifies the Elevation of the Molding. If the axis is specified as "XY", the 4 th  field specifies the offset of the Molding from the Wall Face.

The entries in this section are used to define the lighting conditions for a Room. There are three types of lights, Ambient, Spot, or Directional. There should only be one ambient light with the remainder of the lights being either spot or directional lights. Each entry consists of the light type and the parameters for the light.
The Ambient Light definition should consist of 2 comma separated fields defined as follows:
The Spot Light definition should consist of 9 comma separated fields defined as follows:
The light color may be one of the following predefined colors, "White", "Sky", "Sun", "Florescent" or "Incandesent".

The entries in this section reflect the Door and Option Property Pages for the Catalogs and Cabinets in Solid. They are used to define the Catalog, Door Styles and options for the following [Cabinet] section. This section should  always  contain the Catalog Name, Base and Wall Door Styles and a list of the options to apply to the Cabinets in the following [Cabinets] section. The Cabinets listed in the following [Cabinets] section will be extracted from the specified Catalog by their nomenclature and have the listed Door Styles and Options applied to them. If the Catalog, Door Style or  any  of the options are different for a Cabinet then a new [Catalog] section should be created for the Cabinet and the Cabinet should be placed in a following [Cabinets] section.

rows: Catalog Cabinets should be pulled from
Base Door Style to apply to the Cabinets
Wall Door Style to apply to the Cabinets
Options to apply to the Cabinets

content.data: Catalog Cabinets should be pulled from
Base Door Style to apply to the Cabinets
Wall Door Style to apply to the Cabinets
Options to apply to the Cabinets
The Catalog should reflect the Catalog database name and does not require a CVC extension as one will automatically be appended.
The Door Styles should reflect one of the available Door Styles in the specified Catalog.
The options should reflect one of the available options in the specified Catalog. The "Option" entry consists of 2 comma separated fields defined as follows:

rows: Selected value for the Catalog Option

content.data: Selected value for the Catalog Option

The entries in this section list the Cabinets along with their sizes, hinging and end type information. The Cabinet will be pulled from the Catalog defined in the preceding [Catalog] section by matching it's nomenclature with a Cabinet in the Catalog. The Door Styles and options defined in the preceding [Catalog] section will be applied to the Cabinet.

The Cabinet definitions should consist of 9 comma separated fields defined as follows  (If the Extended ORD Format file is being used and contains a Walls section then the Cabinet definitions should contain an additional 9 positional fields as well) :

rows: Cabinet ID - ID for CW or CV to identify

content.data: Cabinet ID - ID for CW or CV to identify
The Order Entry Number is the Cabinet number as reflected in the "Order Entry" screen in Solid.
The Cabinet Nomenclature should reflect the nomenclature of a Cabinet available in the Catalog defined in the preceding [Catalog] section.
The "Hinge" field (field 6) must be represented by one of the following values:
P = Cabinet has a pair of doors
The "End Types" field (field 7) must be represented by one of the following values:
B = Cabinet has both ends finished
L = Cabinet has left finished end
R = Cabinet has right finished end
N = Cabinet has both ends unfinished
The "Wall Number" field specifies the Wall
A plain number or #-F indicates the front face eg: 3 or 3-F
The "Type" field must be represented by one of the following values:
The "Fill Mode" must be represented by one of the following values:

The "Fixture Type" field must be represented by one of the following values.

The following sample contains a Solid Job with 2 Cabinets exported to an ORD file. The first Cabinet was pulled from the Catalog "Custom Cabinets" and the second was pulled from the Catalog "Generic".

The Header section reflects the current Job Door Style, Materials and Construction. The first [Catalog] section describes the Catalog Name, Door Styles and Options for the first Cabinet pulled from "Custom Cabinets". The Cabinet is listed in the corresponding [Cabinets] section. The second [Catalog] section describes the Catalog settings for the second Cabinet pulled from "Generic"which has different Door Styles. The Cabinet is listed in the following [Cabinets] section.
Comment="John's wife Jane can be reached at 555-555-3456 if John is unavailable"
ShipToComment="Mike is the Supervisor on the Job. Directions, Take a right onto Cherry Avenue once in Tree View Subdivision. Lot 12 is the 5th lot on the left."
BaseDoors="SRP - Routed","Ash","3/8 Lip","Ogee","Swoop Panel Detail","Shallow V","door.ddb"
WallDoors="Arched Raised Panel","Ash","3/8 Lip","Ogee","Swoop Panel Detail","","door.ddb"
BaseDoors="SRP - Routed","Ash","3/8 Lip","Ogee","Swoop Panel Detail","Shallow V","door.ddb"
WallDoors="Arched Raised Panel","Ash","3/8 Lip","Ogee","Swoop Panel Detail","","door.ddb"

The following sample is an example of the extended ORD format that provides for the creation of Walls, Floors and adding Cabinets to the Walls. The Cabinets are visible in layout as they are added to the Walls and not to the order entry list which is the case in the standard ORD format.

The Header section reflects the current Job Door Style, Materials and Construction as well as the Wall and Floor Textures. There is also a setting to set the initial Camera position for the 3D perspective view. The [Walls] section creates three connected Walls while the [Floors] section creates two floor shapes. The [Moldings] section creates some Crown Molding in plan view at an elevation of 92 inches. It also creates some Chair Rail along the Wall in plan view followed by some Chair Rail on the Wall face in elevation view. The [Lights] section sets up three lights, one of each type allowed in Solid (it is good practice to always include an Ambient light). The [Catalog] section describes the Catalog Name, Door Styles and Options for the two Cabinets pulled from "Generic". The two Cabinets are listed in the corresponding [Cabinets] section.
WallEndPanels="Default Slab","White Laminate","","","Bead Raised Panel","Batman Groove","door.ddb"
TallEndPanels="Default Slab","White Laminate","","","Bead Raised Panel","Batman Groove","door.ddb"
